Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2012 08:12AM loriio wrote: Hi August ladies. I'm a June Bug but I wanted to say hello and good luck. Shabby and I were diagnosed around the same time with LCIS. And there are a couple of August ladies that have the same BS I do. I am a little over 2 weeks out from my BMX with TEs and there are good days and bad days. Just make sure you accept help when it's offered and make sure you get lots of rest before and after. Best of luck! Lori
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 06:12PM loriio wrote: Hi August girls. I'm just visiting again with some additional things that have helped me out. I had a BMX (June 26). I didn't have a recliner, and I honestly didn't have too hard a time getting out of bed. I had a much harder time getting back into bed. I didn't have silk pjs but I can see how they would have been helpful. I found sleeping on the couch to be more comfortable than the bed at first because it was easier to prop up. If you have TEs, keep a sweater with you when out running errands. I live in TX (it was 106 today) but when I go to stores, especially the grocery store, I get cold and the pecs contract and the TEs fight back. Very uncomfortable! Also, once I started getting feeling back, all clothes, bras to be irritating. Once I got rid of the drains, I stopped wearing bras or camis. Target has some really soft comfortable t-shirts on sale right now. They are very light and thin so I bought some colorful summer scarves (also on sale at Target and Old Navy right now). I wrap them around to cover my chest. The people who know about the surgery will know why and the people who don't will just think I'm in a fashion rut! Soma pajamas are about the best thing In the world as far as their softness. My sister gave me some in the hospital and I bought another set because I love them so much. Good luck to all! (and thank for letting me sneak in here once in awhile.)
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 06:37AM loriio wrote: Hi Shabby. You are right about catching it early. Mine was only 1mm. I went back and forth for awhile with going ahead with the surgery. So glad I did. The TEs suck. I'm not going to lie. They are weird. I call mine spongebob squareboobs. I was filled with 100ccs during surgery and I go for my next fill on Monday. At first, sleeping on my back wasn't a problem because of the pain meds, but even with the drains out, I still can't sleep on my side because of my pointy TEs. The worst part for me was the pain from the "pocket" they built to hold the TEs. It still feels bruised. Even with that, I've still been able to function to some extent. I'm 3 1/2 weeks out and feeling better. I'm driving now. I haven't worked out yet, mostly because I'm lazy. I'll let you know how the fills go. It's not all bad though. Even they they are weird looking, with just the 100 Ccs, I can tell I'm going to have some cute perky boobs. I was always really small, not even a full A and I'm probably already close to that now. I even have cleavage (which I never had before without a pushup bra)
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 11:39AM loriio wrote: Don't know if I have any suggestions but I can relate. My surgery was 6/26 and I slept ok the first several nights because of he anesthesia and all of the other medications. The night before last, I woke with pain on my lower back. The best I could do was grab and extra pillow, turn it long ways and lean against it starting at the lowest part of my back. I also have a triangle pillow that I place under my knees and that seems to help with the pressure on my back. Last night was the worst so far. I wanted so badly to shift to my side to sleep. Since I have TEs I doubt I will be able to for quite some time. I did tilt slightly to one side, but I still miss sleeping on my side.
Posts.Title: Sleeping & sore back after surgery Amy_AZ ma111

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 09:10AM loriio wrote: Just last night I had a lengthy conversation with a mom of one of my son's friends. She has lupus and had a BMX for DCIS when her oldest child was in 3rd grade. (that daughter is now a senior in college). She hasn't had any problems since with breast cancer. She is going in for a consult with my plastic surgeon next week because she wants to get a lift-not because of any problems with reconstruction just gravity ;/ The doctors have all told her that catching it early and having the BMX was key because treatments such as tamoxifen and chemo would not have been an option for her because of lupus. I know you are scared but it sounds like you and your doctors are on top of things. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 10:52AM loriio wrote: I am feeling much better. I still feel the bruising along my rib cage but it's not excruciating. I have my first fill on Monday. My PS did tell me after surgery that I had strong pecs so I would be sore. I am going to ask about changing the muscle relaxer when I go in on Monday. Thanks for all of the support!

Posts.Title: How did you prepare your children about your surgery Pointvalue Pointvalue

Posts.Content: May 3, 2012 03:57PM loriio wrote: Janet and Beverly, I had a similar experience with my wire for the excisional. When they did the stereotactic, it didnt bother me too much. I was just uncomfortable from laying on the table. However, with the excisional they inserted 2 wires and both hurt like mad. (even though I was "numbed"). I'm usually not too much of a baby when it comes to pain but the nurse thought I was going to dislocate my thumb because I was clenching my fist so hard. I suspect that the pain was mostly from going through the previous biopsy site. Also the 2nd wire went under the nipple so I'm sure that didn't help. Good idea to make it known going forward to use an alternative anesthesia in the event you have to go through it again. Since I'm having a BMX next month, I guess I wont have to worry about it anymore. Best of luck to both of you.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 07:41AM loriio wrote: If the nurse navigator is available in your hospital, I would definitely visit her. I met with mine right after my diagnosis and she walked me step by step through the pathology report and the surgical report. I am seeing her again tomorrow to go over what to expect from my upcoming surgery. I have wonderful doctors but the nurse navigator (Sheree) has been the best resource. I also wonder if Luvmygoats and I had the same navigator. I get the cheery Friday emails too! Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow and I'm a Wreck LeahLeah LeahLeah

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 09:16PM loriio wrote: Hi Audrey.  There is an LCIS board that you can check out where there is lots of "lively" discussion.  It seems to me most people find the stats that support their decision.  The thing to remember is that everyone's pathology is different so there is no "one size fits all" approach.  Which really sucks.  I was diagnosed in March and spent quite a bit of time visiting different doctors.  Including a BS at MD Anderson in Houston.  In my case, all agreed what my best course of action is.  It sounds like you've seen more than one doctor and it's unfortunate there is not a consensus.  The biggest thing to remember is that you have some time to decide.  I recommend finding a doctor that you feel comfortable with and trust.  If you have friends that have had cancer, get opinions on doctors.  If there is a breast center at your local hospital, schedule an appointment with the nurse navigator.  Don't spend too much time on the internet.  At some point, you need to trust your doctor, and yourself.  LCIS is confusing.  I called it "no man's land" when I was first diagnosed because it's ridiculous to me that I was told in one sentence, "It's not cancer."  And the next sentence was, "You should consider Tamoxifen or a PBMX."  It's bizarre.  Just take your time, and make the best decision for you. Best of luck! Lori

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 08:28PM loriio wrote: My heart breaks for you both-losing your mothers so young. I had a PBMX in June for LCIS. My pathology showed a microinvasion of ILC. I am so grateful we caught it early. Breast cancer didn't run in my family (until now) but my 12 year old daughter asked me if now she's going to get it. I hate that she now has this fear. All I can do is take every step I can to take care of myself to be around for her as long as possible. I will join you in praying for a cure. I wish you best of luck on your surgery. ab1234 was right. There will be good days and bad days but my theory going into the surgery was that I was doing it for my kids. They're worth a few bad days.
